title: ‘Melania,’ panned by some film critics, opens with strong ticket sales for a documentary
shortdescription: Despite harsh reviews from film critics, the documentary Melania opened with strong ticket sales, drawing significant audience interest and sparking nationwide discussion on its portrayal of the former First Lady.
description: The documentary Melania, which chronicles the 20 days leading up to First Lady Melania Trump’s life and public role before President Donald Trump’s second inauguration, opened in U.S. theaters on January 30, 2026 with a surprisingly strong box office performance that defied industry expectations and traditional benchmarks for political nonfiction films, grossing an estimated $7 million in its domestic opening weekend and earning what studio representatives and box office analysts described as the largest opening for a non‑concert documentary in more than a decade, a striking achievement considering the film’s exceptionally high production and marketing costs — Amazon MGM Studios paid roughly $40 million for distribution rights and reportedly spent another $35 million on promotion, resulting in a combined investment of about $75 million, a figure far above what most documentary projects incur — and while that level of ticket revenue alone will not be enough to recoup the full expenditure, supporters of the film point to the strong audience turnout, particularly in U.S. states with large Republican constituencies and among older women, who made up a disproportionate share of viewers, as evidence of a distinct niche appeal that translated into better‑than‑anticipated sales and pushed the film into the third spot at the domestic box office behind a pair of genre films, all the while sparking a mix of celebration among its backers and skepticism among critics and commentators who questioned both its artistic merits and the true nature of its box office strength given conflicting reports about empty auditoriums in major cities and anecdotal accounts of minimal advance ticket sales in some urban centers, where venues from New York to Los Angeles reportedly had very low attendance, and leading review aggregators gave Melania overwhelmingly negative ratings from critics, with some commentary describing it as overly flattering, staid, and lacking depth, while audiences awarded it high CinemaScore and audience ratings, illustrating a sharp divide between critical reception and viewer response that mirrors broader cultural and political splits in the United States; further complicating the narrative, global performance has been muted outside the U.S., with low ticket sales in markets like the United Kingdom where it debuted at number 29 at the box office with modest per‑screen averages, and some European screenings recorded extremely sparse attendance — including reports of only one or two tickets sold at certain showings — underscoring the film’s limited international appeal and foreshadowing a long road to profitability if additional revenue streams such as Prime Video streaming and ancillary rights do not significantly bolster earnings, and this mixed performance has ignited broader debate within entertainment circles and political media about the role of political documentaries released during an incumbent administration, the strategic value of such films as part of cultural or political messaging, and the ethics of substantial studio investment in what many observers characterize as a politically charged project that blurs the lines between documentary storytelling and promotional content, with some commentators noting that the film was not screened in advance for critics, leading to a barrage of critical panning, while others pointed out that director Brett Ratner’s involvement — his first major directorial effort since multiple sexual misconduct allegations surfaced against him nearly a decade prior — has further fueled controversy and social media reaction, with online discourse ranging from mockery and satire to conspiracy‑tinged speculation about bulk ticket purchases and claims of manipulated box office figures, and this polarized reaction reflects broader societal tensions over celebrity, politics, and media influence in contemporary culture, leaving the documentary’s legacy defined not just by its ticket sales but by the conversation it has generated nationwide.

title: Betty Boop and ‘Blondie’ Enter the Public Domain in 2026, Accompanied by a Trio of Detectives
shortdescription: Beloved characters Betty Boop and Blondie officially enter the public domain in 2026, joined by several classic detective characters, opening new creative possibilities for artists and publishers.
description: Several iconic characters from early American animation, comics, and pulp fiction enter the public domain in 2026, led by Betty Boop and Blondie, alongside a trio of classic detective characters whose copyrights expire under U.S. law. Betty Boop, who first appeared in early 1930s animated shorts, remains one of the most recognizable figures from the golden age of animation, symbolizing the Jazz Age with her flapper style, musical roots, and playful independence, though only her earliest black-and-white versions are included in the public domain while later design elements remain protected. Blondie, created by cartoonist Chic Young, also becomes free to use in her original form, reflecting the early domestic-comedy tone of the strip before decades of later character development that continues to be copyrighted. Joining them are several early detective characters from serialized fiction, highlighting the enduring popularity of crime-solving narratives that shaped pulp magazines and popular storytelling in the early 20th century. The transition of these works into the public domain allows creators to adapt, remix, and reinterpret them without licensing fees, encouraging new films, books, artwork, merchandise, and educational uses, while also requiring careful attention to legal boundaries between public-domain material and still-protected trademarks or later creative additions. Intellectual property experts emphasize that while names, stories, and visual elements from the original works are free to use, modern branding, distinctive catchphrases, and updated designs may still be legally restricted. The arrival of these characters into the public domain reflects the broader cultural importance of copyright expiration, which ensures that creative works eventually become part of shared cultural heritage rather than remaining indefinitely controlled by private entities. In recent years, newly public-domain characters have inspired a wave of independent adaptations and scholarly reexaminations, demonstrating how older works can gain renewed relevance when freed from exclusive ownership. At the same time, major studios and rights holders often respond by reinforcing trademark protections or releasing updated versions to maintain commercial control, creating a dynamic tension between open access and brand preservation. The public-domain debut of Betty Boop, Blondie, and the accompanying detectives underscores the evolving lifecycle of intellectual property and the role public access plays in sustaining creativity, cultural memory, and innovation across generations.

title: Isiah Whitlock Jr., Actor From ‘The Wire,’ ‘Veep’ and Spike Lee Films, Dies at 71
shortdescription: Isiah Whitlock Jr., the acclaimed character actor known for his work on ‘The Wire,’ ‘Veep,’ and multiple Spike Lee films, has died at the age of 71.
description: Isiah Whitlock Jr., a widely respected character actor whose commanding presence and distinctive voice made him a standout across television, film, and theater, has died at the age of 71, leaving behind a legacy defined by versatility, depth, and cultural impact. Whitlock was best known for portraying State Senator Clay Davis on the HBO drama ‘The Wire,’ a role that earned him lasting recognition for blending charisma, humor, and moral ambiguity into a character that became one of the series’ most memorable figures and a sharp embodiment of political corruption within the show’s broader critique of institutional power. His delivery of dialogue, particularly his emphatic catchphrases, became iconic among fans and contributed to the enduring popularity of the series. Beyond ‘The Wire,’ Whitlock demonstrated his range on the political satire ‘Veep,’ where he showcased a sharp comedic sensibility and an ability to thrive in fast-paced, dialogue-heavy storytelling. His career was also closely linked to filmmaker Spike Lee, with whom he collaborated on several films that explored race, politics, and social justice in America, roles that reflected Whitlock’s commitment to portraying complex Black characters with intelligence and authority. Trained as a classical stage actor, Whitlock maintained deep roots in theater, where his powerful voice and disciplined technique earned him admiration from peers and directors alike, even when his work was less visible to mainstream audiences. Over decades, he became a familiar and trusted presence in supporting roles, capable of elevating scenes through subtlety and gravitas rather than spectacle. Colleagues often described him as generous, professional, and deeply committed to his craft, qualities that made him a valued collaborator on set and a mentor to younger performers. His passing prompted tributes from across the entertainment industry, with many highlighting not only his most famous roles but also the consistency and integrity of his career. Isiah Whitlock Jr.’s death marks the loss of an actor who exemplified the importance of character work in storytelling, and his performances continue to resonate through a body of work that captured the complexities, contradictions, and rhythms of American life.

title: Movie Review: ‘The Plague’ Dives Into a Sink-or-Swim Water Polo Camp
shortdescription: ‘The Plague’ explores the brutal pressures of a hyper-competitive youth water polo camp, using physical endurance and psychological strain to examine ambition, conformity, and survival.
description: ‘The Plague’ plunges viewers into the claustrophobic and unforgiving world of an elite youth water polo camp, where the line between discipline and cruelty becomes increasingly blurred and survival depends as much on mental resilience as physical stamina. Set almost entirely within the confines of the camp, the film follows a group of teenage athletes subjected to relentless drills, strict hierarchy, and an unspoken code that rewards dominance while punishing vulnerability, creating an environment that feels less like a training ground and more like a social experiment. The film’s title serves as a metaphor for the toxic dynamics that spread among the players, as fear, peer pressure, and ambition infect the group and reshape individual behavior. Rather than focusing on the sport itself as spectacle, the director uses water polo as a backdrop to explore broader themes of power, masculinity, and the cost of belonging, emphasizing how authority figures enable harmful systems through silence or indifference. The camera lingers on exhaustion, bruises, and quiet moments of doubt, allowing tension to build gradually and making the pool feel like both a proving ground and a trap. Performances from the young cast are raw and convincing, capturing the volatility of adolescence intensified by competition and isolation, while dialogue is sparse, relying instead on body language and atmosphere to convey emotional stakes. The film resists easy heroes or villains, portraying a culture in which cruelty is normalized and survival often requires complicity, a choice that may unsettle viewers but reinforces the film’s critique of win-at-all-costs mentalities. Visually, ‘The Plague’ adopts a stark, almost oppressive aesthetic, with harsh lighting and confined framing that mirror the characters’ lack of escape, while the sound design amplifies every splash, whistle, and labored breath to heighten immersion. Though the pacing is deliberately measured, the mounting sense of dread keeps the narrative engaging, culminating in moments that force characters to confront the moral consequences of their choices. ‘The Plague’ may not appeal to audiences seeking a traditional sports drama, but its willingness to interrogate the darker side of competitive youth culture gives it a sharp edge, making it a thought-provoking and unsettling examination of what it means to endure, conform, or break away when pushed to the brink.

title: Movie Review: Daisy Ridley Holds Onto Hope in the Zombie Thriller ‘We Bury the Dead’
shortdescription: Daisy Ridley delivers a restrained and emotionally grounded performance in the zombie thriller ‘We Bury the Dead,’ a film that favors human resilience over genre spectacle.
description: ‘We Bury the Dead’ offers a contemplative take on the zombie genre, anchored by a quietly powerful performance from Daisy Ridley that reframes survival as an act of emotional endurance rather than physical dominance. Set in the aftermath of a devastating and unexplained outbreak, the film follows Ridley’s character as she navigates a world stripped of structure, safety, and certainty, where the presence of the undead is less shocking than the persistence of grief and moral fatigue among the living. Rather than relying on constant action or graphic horror, the film adopts a measured pace, allowing moments of silence, reflection, and hesitation to carry as much weight as moments of danger. Ridley portrays a protagonist defined by restraint, conveying fear, exhaustion, and determination through subtle expressions and controlled movement, reinforcing the film’s central theme that hope survives not through heroics but through small, deliberate choices. The direction emphasizes atmosphere over spectacle, using desaturated visuals, abandoned landscapes, and minimal dialogue to create a sense of isolation that feels both intimate and oppressive. Zombies remain an ever-present threat, but they function more as a backdrop to the film’s exploration of loss, responsibility, and the ethical compromises required to keep going. Supporting characters serve as mirrors to Ridley’s journey, representing different responses to catastrophe, from emotional withdrawal to ruthless pragmatism, without overwhelming the narrative’s focus on internal struggle. The screenplay resists the temptation to overexplain the origins of the outbreak, instead prioritizing character psychology and the slow erosion of trust and certainty, a choice that may frustrate viewers seeking clear answers but ultimately strengthens the film’s emotional resonance. Sound design and score are used sparingly, heightening tension through absence rather than excess, while the film’s climactic moments feel earned precisely because they are understated. ‘We Bury the Dead’ does not aim to reinvent the zombie genre, but its commitment to emotional authenticity and its refusal to sensationalize violence give it a distinct identity, and Daisy Ridley’s performance ensures that the story lingers as a meditation on grief, perseverance, and the fragile decision to keep hoping when the world has already ended.

title: Chevy Chase Is Under the Spotlight in a New Documentary, Warts and All — and He’s OK With It
shortdescription: A new documentary takes an unflinching look at Chevy Chase’s career, controversies, and comedic legacy, with the actor embracing a portrait that includes both his brilliance and his flaws.
description: A new documentary places Chevy Chase firmly under the spotlight, offering an unvarnished examination of his groundbreaking career, turbulent reputation, and lasting influence on American comedy, and notably, the actor appears largely at peace with the candid portrayal. The film traces Chase’s rise as one of the original breakout stars of ‘Saturday Night Live,’ where his physical comedy, sharp timing, and confident persona helped define the show’s early identity and set the template for modern sketch comedy stardom. From there, the documentary follows his transition to film, highlighting iconic roles in comedies that became cultural touchstones and cemented his status as a box-office draw during the late 1970s and 1980s. At the same time, the documentary does not shy away from the controversies that have long surrounded Chase, including reports of difficult behavior on sets, conflicts with colleagues, and a reputation that often overshadowed his talent. Through interviews with collaborators, critics, and Chase himself, the film presents a complex portrait of an artist whose confidence and ambition sometimes crossed into arrogance, creating lasting friction in professional relationships. Rather than attempting to rehabilitate his image or offer simple explanations, the documentary allows conflicting perspectives to coexist, inviting viewers to grapple with the tension between creative brilliance and personal shortcomings. Chase’s own reflections add another layer, as he acknowledges mistakes and misunderstandings while also defending his contributions and comedic instincts, suggesting a self-awareness shaped by time and distance from the peak of his fame. The film also situates Chase within a broader cultural context, examining how shifts in workplace norms, comedy styles, and expectations of accountability have reshaped how his behavior is interpreted today. By revisiting both his successes and missteps, the documentary raises questions about how legacies are formed and whether it is possible—or necessary—to separate an artist’s work from their personal conduct. Ultimately, the film’s strength lies in its refusal to smooth over uncomfortable truths, presenting Chevy Chase as neither a villain nor a victim but as a complicated figure whose impact on comedy remains undeniable. In embracing a portrait that includes flaws alongside achievements, the documentary offers a nuanced exploration of fame, ego, and the evolving standards by which cultural icons are judged, and Chase’s apparent acceptance of this approach gives the film an honesty that resonates beyond nostalgia.

title: ‘Avatar’ and ‘Marty Supreme’ Propel Strong Ticket Sales to Wrap a Turbulent 2025 for Hollywood
shortdescription: Strong box office performances from ‘Avatar’ and ‘Marty Supreme’ helped Hollywood end a turbulent 2025 on a high note, offering renewed optimism for theaters and studios alike.
description: Hollywood closed out a turbulent 2025 with a welcome boost at the box office as strong ticket sales driven by ‘Avatar’ and ‘Marty Supreme’ helped restore momentum to an industry that spent much of the year navigating uncertainty, shifting audience habits, and lingering economic pressures. After a year marked by uneven release schedules, cautious studio spending, and concerns over theatrical attendance, the late-year success of these two films underscored the continued power of event cinema to draw audiences back to theaters. ‘Avatar,’ returning audiences to its visually immersive world, once again demonstrated the franchise’s global appeal, attracting moviegoers seeking a large-scale cinematic experience best enjoyed on the biggest screens available. Meanwhile, ‘Marty Supreme,’ though very different in tone and scope, emerged as a surprise driver of ticket sales, benefiting from strong word of mouth, targeted marketing, and broad demographic appeal that helped sustain momentum beyond its opening weekend. Industry analysts noted that the combined success of these films highlighted the importance of variety in theatrical offerings, proving that both spectacle-driven blockbusters and character-focused stories can coexist as box office anchors. Throughout 2025, Hollywood faced headwinds ranging from production slowdowns and labor tensions to rising costs and competition from streaming platforms, all of which contributed to volatility in theatrical revenue. The late surge in ticket sales offered a counter-narrative, suggesting that audiences remain willing to show up for films that deliver clear value and distinct theatrical experiences. Studio executives and theater owners alike pointed to the performance of ‘Avatar’ and ‘Marty Supreme’ as evidence that strategic release timing, strong marketing, and compelling storytelling remain critical factors in box office success. While overall annual totals still reflected the challenges of the year, the strong finish helped narrow gaps and provided a psychological boost heading into 2026. As Hollywood looks ahead, the year-end results reinforced cautious optimism that the industry can stabilize and grow by focusing on quality, franchise strength, and audience engagement, using the lessons of 2025 to chart a more resilient path forward for theatrical filmmaking.

title: Brigitte Bardot, 1960s French Sex Symbol Turned Militant Animal Rights Activist, Dies at 91
shortdescription: Brigitte Bardot, the iconic French film star who became a global sex symbol in the 1960s before reinventing herself as a fierce animal rights activist, has died at the age of 91.
description: Brigitte Bardot, the French actress whose beauty, screen presence, and unapologetic sensuality made her one of the most famous women in the world during the 1960s before she later abandoned cinema to become a militant animal rights activist, has died at the age of 91, marking the end of a life that bridged celebrity, controversy, and activism. Bardot rose to international fame during the postwar era, redefining female stardom with a natural, rebellious allure that contrasted sharply with the polished Hollywood icons of the time, and her performances helped usher in a new image of liberated femininity that resonated across Europe and beyond. Films such as those that defined her career made her a symbol of sexual freedom and cultural change, while her off-screen persona—marked by candor, defiance of convention, and frequent clashes with authority—only amplified her public fascination. At the height of her fame, Bardot shocked audiences and the film industry by walking away from acting in her late 30s, retreating from public life at a time when her popularity remained strong. She redirected her energy toward animal welfare, founding an organization dedicated to protecting animals and becoming one of the most outspoken and uncompromising advocates for animal rights in Europe. Her activism was relentless and often controversial, marked by graphic campaigns, confrontations with governments, and statements that drew both praise and condemnation. Over the decades, Bardot’s political views and blunt rhetoric sparked repeated criticism and legal trouble, complicating her legacy and overshadowing aspects of her humanitarian work. Yet supporters argued that her unwavering commitment brought unprecedented attention to animal cruelty and forced uncomfortable conversations into the public sphere. Bardot lived largely reclusively in later years, maintaining a distance from the entertainment world she once dominated while remaining fiercely engaged in activism. Her death prompts renewed reflection on a life that defied easy categorization, encompassing cinematic influence, cultural upheaval, personal withdrawal, and uncompromising advocacy. Brigitte Bardot leaves behind a complex legacy as both a defining icon of 20th-century cinema and a polarizing figure whose transformation from screen legend to activist reshaped how fame can be wielded long after the spotlight fades.

title: What Music and Television to Stream: A New Year’s Eve Tradition and a ‘Stranger Things’ Sendoff
shortdescription: From familiar New Year’s Eve music traditions to a nostalgic farewell to ‘Stranger Things,’ streaming platforms offer a mix of comfort, celebration, and closure to ring in the new year.
description: As New Year’s Eve arrives, streaming platforms are leaning into a blend of tradition and transition, offering audiences music and television options that reflect both the comfort of year-end rituals and the anticipation of cultural milestones coming to a close, including a notable sendoff connected to ‘Stranger Things.’ For many viewers, ringing in the new year is inseparable from familiar musical experiences, whether it is revisiting classic performances, countdown specials, or curated playlists designed to capture the reflective and celebratory mood of the night. Streaming services have expanded these offerings with themed collections that pair nostalgia with convenience, allowing users to soundtrack their evenings with everything from timeless pop standards to contemporary hits that defined the year now ending. On the television side, New Year’s Eve programming continues to serve as a communal experience, even in the era of on-demand viewing, with concerts, variety specials, and retrospective shows providing a shared cultural rhythm as the clock approaches midnight. This year’s streaming landscape also carries an added emotional note with content tied to the conclusion of ‘Stranger Things,’ a series that has become a defining pop culture touchstone over the past decade. As fans prepare to say goodbye to the show’s characters and storylines, streaming platforms are highlighting previous seasons, companion content, and curated recommendations that invite viewers to reflect on the series’ impact and relive key moments. The pairing of New Year’s Eve traditions with a major television farewell underscores how streaming has reshaped the way audiences mark time, blending personal rituals with collective cultural moments. Rather than tuning into a single broadcast, viewers now assemble their own year-end experiences, mixing music, television, and memory at their own pace. Industry observers note that this flexibility has transformed holidays into personalized media events, while still preserving the emotional pull of shared references like iconic shows and annual countdowns. As the year turns, the available streaming choices offer more than entertainment, providing a sense of continuity, closure, and anticipation that mirrors the broader transition into a new chapter. Whether through a familiar song played at midnight or a final revisit to a beloved series, streaming content continues to shape how audiences say goodbye to one year and welcome the next.

title: Bad Bunny’s ‘Debí Tirar Más Fotos’ Could Make Grammy History
shortdescription: Bad Bunny’s latest project ‘Debí Tirar Más Fotos’ is being hailed as a potential Grammy history-maker, reflecting the global impact and artistic evolution of the superstar.
description: Bad Bunny’s ‘Debí Tirar Más Fotos’ has emerged as a landmark release that could make Grammy history, underscoring the Puerto Rican superstar’s continued expansion of Latin music’s influence on the global stage. The project, praised for its emotional depth and stylistic ambition, blends reggaeton, Latin pop, and introspective storytelling in a way that challenges traditional genre boundaries while remaining deeply personal. Industry observers note that the album’s critical reception and commercial performance position it as a strong contender across major Grammy categories, including those historically dominated by English-language releases, highlighting the growing recognition of Spanish-language music within the Recording Academy. ‘Debí Tirar Más Fotos’ reflects a reflective turn in Bad Bunny’s artistry, with lyrics that explore memory, fame, vulnerability, and the passage of time, resonating with audiences far beyond his core fan base. The project’s title itself signals a sense of nostalgia and self-awareness, themes that are woven throughout the album’s production choices and narrative arc. Musically, the album balances innovation with accessibility, pairing experimental sounds with melodies that have proven durable across streaming platforms and radio. Its success reinforces Bad Bunny’s role not just as a chart-topping artist but as a cultural figure shaping conversations about language, identity, and representation in mainstream music. If the album secures major Grammy recognition, it would mark another milestone in the gradual dismantling of barriers that have historically limited non-English works within the awards landscape. Such an outcome would also build on recent shifts at the Grammys toward greater inclusivity, signaling that global audiences and artistic merit increasingly outweigh linguistic divides. As awards season approaches, ‘Debí Tirar Más Fotos’ stands as both a personal statement and a broader symbol of Latin music’s evolving place in global pop culture, with the potential to redefine what Grammy success looks like in an increasingly interconnected musical world.
